Award.AbstractNarration:
The artist April Waters is an accomplished painter focused primarily on water and the scientists who study it. Her deployment to Palmer Station, Antarctica will afford her the opportunity to observe, sketch. and produce study-paintings of the ocean, sea ice. icebergs, and glaciers around the station that will inform her large-scale canvasses, which she will paint in her home studio. The focus on water is intended to bring a fresh and unique perspective to observe and express the Antarctic wilderness. Her goal is to communicate the beauty as well as the vulnerability of Antarctica's ecosystem and help communicate the region's sense of wonder to the public. Her unique perspective will provide a distinctive addition to the Antarctic Artists and Writers portfolio.

This artist's portfolio of oil paintings focused on water has afforded her multiple opportunities to speak about water issues in forums that bring together scientists, government officials and the public. Her work in Antarctica will be a natural extension of her prior work. Her new work, comprised of 10-12 large canvasses, will be exhibited across the state of Oregon, with multiple on-going opportunities to speak with students and the public about her Antarctic experiences. She will also exhibit at the NCAR Art Gallery in Boulder, Colorado. Over an extended period, her work will bring awareness and appreciation of Antarctica to a significant audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In November of 2018, I had the opportunity to travel to Palmer Station as a participant in the Nation Science Foundation's Artists and Writers Program.  

During my stay at Palmer, I painted, drew, and photographed Marr Glacier, Arthur Harbor, Hero Inlet, Anvers Island and multiple other islands and coves. There were mesmerizing sunrises and sunsets and exciting zodiac rides to see icebergs and wildlife. As often as possible, I went out with the scientists on the zodiacs as they gathered samples. I gathered information about the Long-Term Ecological Research project so that I can include it in my future exhibitions and public talks. 

I am currently working on a 72' by 108" oil painting for my upcoming exhibitions. There will be 10-12 paintings that will speak to the beauty and vulnerability of Antarctica's fragile and susceptible ecosystem.

The first three exhibitions will be at the Hallie Ford Art Museum in Salem, Oregon, the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colorado and the LaSells Stewart Center Gallery at Oregon State University in Corvallis. A selection of the paintings may also be exhibited at the Chilean Embassy in Santiago through the United States Department of State, Art in Embassies program.

In addition to the artwork produced and exhibited, there will be multiple public presentations over the next several years in which I will share my experience at Palmer and the work it inspired.
